unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Purple Candies
question_text:
A company published its percentages for colors of candy included in its jumbo packs. Here they are:
A firm was hired to perform a chi-square goodness of fit test. What is the alternative hypothesis and what is the expected number of purple candies given there were $40$ bags randomly selected which included $960$ total candies sampled?
What is the alternative hypothesis and what is the expected number of purple candies given there were $40$ bags randomly selected which included $960$ total candies sampled?

choices.text:
$H_{a}$: The proportions of colors in the jumbo bags is the same as what the company claims.
Expected number of purple candies: $6$

$H_{a}$: The proportions of colors in the jumbo bags is not the same as what the company claims.
Expected number of purple candies: $6$

$H_{a}$: The proportions of colors in the jumbo bags is not the same as what the company claims.
Expected number of purple candies: $144$

$H_{a}$: The proportions of candy colors should all be the same.
Expected number of purple candies: $144$

Ha: The proportions of colors in the jumbo bags is the same as what the company claims.
Expected number of purple candies: 96

solution:
Solution

The chi-square test for goodness of fit measures the fit between what is expected and what is observed. It is a test of significance that has hypotheses and expected values.

The null hypothesis states that the proportions are what is expected. In this case, we would expect the 6
colors to show up in candy bags in the same proportions as stated by the company. The alternative hypothesis states that these proportions are not the same as what the company claims.

To calculate expected values you would multiply the given proportions times the number examined. In this case we expect 15%
purple candies so (0.15)(960)=144
candies.

So, Choice 'C' is correct.
